stream_context.summary: Kaze codes and tests the Mole Hideout section of the western-themed course, creating a small Monty-Mole boss encounter and showing a brand-new collision system.

development_findings.summary: Kaze replaced the original SM64 collision with a fully custom system that is "so much more stable," even letting Mario walk in tight, glitch-prone spots without getting stuck.
development_findings.quote: I made a completely new collision system. I said, fuck Mario 64's collision. It is unusable. We have our completely own collision system now, and it's so much more stable.

development_findings.summary: The new collision accidentally removes BLJ; Kaze wants to preserve intentional, skill-based glitches and may re-enable BLJ in specific spots.
development_findings.quote: I'm not trying to prevent the BLJ… It just so happened to remove BLJ and I consider that a bad thing.

development_findings.summary: Monty-Mole enemy behaviour rewritten: each mole throws a rock directly at Mario’s current position (non-predictive) using a frame-based velocity calculation Kaze derived on stream.
development_findings.quote: It shoots exactly where Mario is at. It's not predictive.

development_findings.summary: Boss concept finalized: five moles pop from random holes around a circular arena; stomping all of them yields a star and coin drops. Speed and spawn timing vary per mole.
development_findings.quote: We'll just have them be dizzy and go in and then they will disappear… nine felt too busy, so five is fine. Bonk them all to win.

development_findings.summary: Coins spawn safety check uses SM64’s internal ‘coin counter’ guard; Kaze adjusted Y-velocity and amount (1–2 coins per mole).
Kaze wrestled with projectile-arc math, tried ChatGPT, then derived a simple sum-of-frames solution himself.
development_findings.quote: ChatGPT is not being useful here, let's just make up bullshit until it works.

development_findings.summary: Minimum rock velocity added to guarantee the projectile travels far enough regardless of Mario’s height difference.
Camera and spawn-side issues fixed by making all moles right-handed and offsetting rock origin.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is on day ~40 of a calorie cut, down ~15 lbs, feeling physically better and confident.
context_findings.quote: Dude, I'm starting to look fucking chiseled… once I eat carbs again it's gonna look crazy.

context_findings.summary: He treats criticism by searching for the underlying emotion rather than literal suggestions, believing experienced critics often focus on arbitrary metrics.
context_findings.quote: Whenever I receive criticism… I try to look at the underlying feeling instead of their actual critique.

context_findings.summary: Plans to launch a Kickstarter for an original 3D platformer shortly after Return to Yoshi's Island releases.
context_findings.quote: Alongside the release of Return to Yoshi's Island I'll probably launch a Kickstarter for my own game and then transition to working on that.

context_findings.summary: Mentions ad-sponsorship troubles: a Chinese handheld company disliked his unconventional promo; highlights cautious attitude toward sponsorships.
context_findings.quote: They were so mad at me… you're offering me a $150 device to upload to my main channel where an ad usually costs $3,000—yeah, no way.

context_findings.summary: Light personal banter about aging, looks, and hair loss; spouse Zeina not home during stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina (animator) was absent; Kaze joked about her floor being ‘stinky’.

key_stories.title: Replacing SM64 Collision
key_stories.summary: Fed up with unstable native collision, Kaze wrote an entirely new system that handles complex geometry smoothly.
key_stories.challenge: Original SM64 collision causes snagging, BLJ exploits, and design limitations.
key_stories.process: Scrapped Nintendo code; implemented custom sweep tests and ceilings; live demoed tight-space traversal.
key_stories.outcome: Stable movement; some legacy glitches (BLJ) disappeared, prompting future tweak discussions.
key_stories.key_quote: We have our completely own collision system now. It literally just works.

key_stories.title: Monty-Mole Boss Iteration
key_stories.summary: Kaze brainstormed, coded, and refined a simple yet engaging boss featuring five rock-throwing moles.
key_stories.challenge: Initial ideas (tanks, survival waves) felt thematically off or too chaotic.
key_stories.process: Chat feedback, random-hole logic, variable speed, coin rewards, hit detection fixes.
key_stories.outcome: Functional prototype finished on stream; animations and polishing left.
key_stories.key_quote: Nine Monty Moles is too much; five that switch holes works just fine.

key_stories.title: Sponsor Ad Backfire
key_stories.summary: A handheld emulator company demanded a conventional one-minute promo; Kaze’s comedic ad upset them.
key_stories.challenge: Mismatch between brand expectations and Kaze’s creative style.
key_stories.process: Produced irreverent ad referencing potential ‘Chinese scam’; ignored follow-up complaints.
key_stories.outcome: No legal action; reinforced his selective approach to sponsorships.
key_stories.key_quote: I think I gave them an awesome ad—they were very upset at me.
